problem: The saw was running but generating excessive heat in both brush holders, with visible smoking and burning. Both brushes were getting scalding hot at 70-80°C, indicating the armature was burnt out.
failure_reason: Repair was postponed because the armature needed to be ordered and would take 1-2 weeks to arrive

problem: The tool had power but was not running. Wrong brushes had been previously installed by someone else, and there was a burnt brush holder connection with damaged connectors.
The saw was making a horrible burning sound when stopping, initially suspected to be bearing problems.
The impact wrench had a gearbox problem where the anvil was bound up and wouldn't turn freely due to cold welding between the steel components.
Customer reported the motor was burnt out, not cutting straight, and smoking heavily instead of cutting. Motor was actually fine but blade was installed backwards.
The cordless miter saw was running and working properly but was stuck in one angle position and couldn't be adjusted due to a broken plastic lever mechanism.
A nearly new 2024 hammer drill that had no power and wouldn't run. The brushes were completely jammed with mud, sand, cement dust, and corrosion, preventing them from making contact.

The forward/reverse change lever was broken - it would go forward but couldn't get it on reverse unless you poke it with your finger. One of the little ends had snapped off, commonly happens if these get a bang or put down wrong or they fall over, or something drops on them.

The speed selector switch was not working - the lights were working but it wasn't letting you select any other speed. It was stuck on high speed, though often they fail in low speed making them basically worthless. The problem was caused by dust getting inside the switch mechanism, as these switches act like little bellows that suck dust in every time they're pressed and released.
Tool not making any sound when triggered, light comes on but motor won't run at all, completely dead motor with no attempt to turn
failure_reason: Switch costs €100 and it's a 10-year-old DC motor tool, not worth repairing as motor will likely fail soon after and better to replace with new brushless version

problem: Bearings failed and housing melted due to overheating, bearing melted the plastic housing causing parts to be stuck together, fan covered in melted plastic residue
Not hammering and motor jammed up, mechanism broken internally, spring compressed and piston disengaged causing motor to jam
Bit not staying in the drill, falls out when pulled on during use
Motor burnt out, brushes melted into the body, armature windings burnt and copper segments dead or shorted out from extensive use
failure_reason: Armature, end bell, brushes and cap all need replacement costing €70-80, not worth it when new grinder costs €130, plus previous repair attempt already failed

problem: Motor burnt out, armature heavily worn and rounded at edges, windings and commutator segments burnt out and shorted from tremendous amount of work use
failure_reason: Extensive motor damage including armature wear makes repair not cost effective

problem: Switch totally worn out and losing contact, tool still runs but switch is failing
failure_reason: Switch costs €70 and tool can be bought new for €90-100, not cost effective to repair

problem: Machine was making noise and had performance issues, also had a kinked power cord that was never installed correctly
18 volt 3/4 inch impact gun was making bad noise and had seized bearing that caused plastic housing to melt from friction. Tool had been used outside in all weather conditions by steel fabricator
Machine was making noise indicating brush issues and had a broken power cord with damaged lead
SDS drill was not holding bits properly due to worn keyways in tool holder, plus had perished rubber rings and debris inside requiring complete disassembly and cleaning
Magnetic drill had electrical problems with blown armature that was raised up and eating away brushes
failure_reason: Repair cost of approximately 400 euros for new motor unit makes it uneconomical compared to buying new equivalent machine for 600 euros

problem: Customer reported the grinder went 'bang' but upon inspection no fault could be identified - machine ran normally with no obvious defects
Tool needed cleaning due to buildup of grease, dirt, oil and skin around the switch area
Tool had done a fair bit of work and needed cleaning of grease and dirt buildup
Something was binding up inside the tool, steel bush had moved out of position and was not flush
Switch needed repair or cleaning
Spring was not holding properly, spring was completely gone that holds up the steel ball in the tool holder
Tool holder issue requiring replacement of steel ball and spring
Switch needed repair or cleaning
Battery pack was badly corroded and in poor condition
failure_reason: Battery was too badly corroded to repair

problem: One side of the double charger is completely dead and not charging batteries. The board shows signs of water damage with rust marks.
failure_reason: Water damage to the charging board, replacement parts not available separately

problem: Chuck is totally rusted solid and won't open, and the motor has burnt windings with copper winding turned black instead of proper color.
Tool was covered in thick black paint that prevented the switch from working properly.
Motor windings are all black, fan is melted onto the brush holder, and water damage throughout. Motor has overheated and burned out.
failure_reason: Extensive motor damage and water damage, not cost effective to repair given low tool price

problem: Trigger not going through all speeds properly, switch connector got hot and melted/burnt the wire.
Gearbox not dropping into gear properly due to dirt buildup preventing selector from engaging fully, and chuck is seized.
No specific problem mentioned, appeared to be working fine when tested.
Wiring has melted through from excessive current draw, connectors are totally melted, and wires melted onto plastic body creating short circuit risk.
failure_reason: Too risky to repair due to melted wiring creating battery short circuit hazard

problem: Motor windings are burnt and wrong color, contacts are cooked from overheating, brushes and end caps are melted.
failure_reason: Motor resistance too high from burning, would overheat again quickly even after brush replacement

problem: Power cord damaged, blades completely broken and clogged with sawdust, depth adjustment mechanism jammed with rust, and motor vents clogged with debris.
component: power cord, blades, and depth adjustment

problem: Tool holder shattered and fell apart, a common fault on these heavy duty cordless reciprocating saws used by fire departments for rescue work and taking cars apart
Nail gun was jammed and not firing properly, with the piston stuck and unable to return to proper position
Motor was burnt out and not starting, producing a burning smell and getting very hot. This DIY grade drill was pushed too hard beyond its limits
Charger was completely dead with no lights or response, likely had a board failure
failure_reason: Not worth repairing due to cost - would be more expensive to diagnose and repair the board than to buy a new charger

problem: Tool was making a high pitched whining sound and had no power getting through despite the switch working and controller trying to engage
failure_reason: All components are one integrated piece, so replacing any failed part costs as much as buying a new tool

problem: Brushes were completely worn out, tool was old and rusty but motor and other components were still in good condition
Forward/reverse switch was physically damaged and buried on both sides, couldn't change direction or speed. The connector and switch were both damaged beyond repair
failure_reason: Switch was physically destroyed (possibly run over by vehicle), and the part cannot be purchased separately - would need to replace entire assembly

problem: Motor brushes were completely worn down to nothing, with one brush lead coming out easily and springs burnt through. The brush had worn down to the wire literally

Tool was completely dead with melted plastic housing around the plunger assembly. The aluminum housing had gotten hot enough to literally liquify and melt the plastic, and wiring was discolored from extreme heat
failure_reason: Catastrophic thermal damage - plastic housing melted and aluminum discolored from extreme overheating, too extensively damaged to repair

problem: Multiple NiCad battery packs were heavily corroded with green corrosion on contacts, battery acid had leaked out destroying the cells, and one pack had completely corroded leads
failure_reason: Extensive corrosion damage and leaked battery acid destroyed the cells beyond repair, not economically viable to fix old NiCad technology

problem: Charger was heavily corroded and showing no voltage output, contacts were green with corrosion from sitting in storage
failure_reason: Extensive corrosion damage throughout, not economically viable to repair

problem: Magnesium base was broken and the guard housing/clip assembly was also damaged, likely from being dropped. Motor still runs but structural components are damaged
failure_reason: Repair pending - needs parts ordered and customer approval due to high repair cost relative to tool value

problem: Motor brushes were worn out and making noise, tool needed brush replacement for continued operation
Motor wouldn't start in bump mode, would only start on plunge mode due to dirty trigger contacts that were blocked and not always engaging the motor
Burnt and melted brush holders, worn brushes, heavy use causing high amp draw that melted components
Tool was engaging but not rotating, clutch gear had a single tooth that broke off and was found inside the machine
Machine was down on power, started smoking after running for a while, motor field was burnt and generating too much heat, worn brushes
Motor was burnt out, lost magnetism in field due to overheating, switch also failed
failure_reason: Motor field lost magnetism due to overheating, switch also failed, not economical to repair

problem: Switch failure, trigger not working properly
failure_reason: Switch replacement cost too high relative to tool value, not economical to repair

problem: Gearbox issue not going fully into speed, trigger problem, motor appears burnt out
failure_reason: Multiple failures including gearbox and trigger, not economical to repair

problem: Switch completely dead, motor burnt out
Chisel was stuck in the chuck, chuck mechanism was rusted and needed cleaning and regreasing, cable gland was pulled out
The live wire in the power cord is exposed and damaged, creating a safety hazard. Motor runs but chuck is not turning, appears to be a gear engagement issue where the drill is not properly in gear.
Armature is burnt out with raised segments and big gaps, extremely noisy operation with a lot of slop indicating gears are also damaged.
failure_reason: Not economical to repair - armature costs €45 while new grinder costs €60, also needs gears and brushes

problem: Brushed motor not running properly, motor brushes are cracked and overheated causing them to stick in the holder, armature commutator showing signs of heat damage.
Chuck is seized and getting hot, trigger is starting to fail intermittently.

Power cord has 10-11 cuts and damage with exposed live and neutral wires, motor brushes are worn, bearing screws have come loose causing bearing movement and gear rubbing, one screw head worn completely through from rubbing.
No apparent problem found during testing, tool is running and impacting properly, may have been sent in for intermittent starting issues common to Milwaukee brushless tools.
Initially would not run, then started running intermittently, motor brushes are nearly worn out and sticking.
Chuck/anvil has excessive wear from thousands of tek screws, gearbox is worn out, and switch is failing and not operating correctly.
failure_reason: Not economical to repair - would need anvil, spindle, gearbox components, and switch replacement

problem: Tool holder/chuck not holding bits properly, switch operation feels wrong and tool only operates in low speed.
Bearing failure causing grinder to barely turn, 605 bearing has collapsed and failed, spring latch for guard adjustment is broken.
Machine was making noise and had a kinked power cord that was never installed correctly, with the cord being damaged near where a screw could go through the cable
18V 3/4 inch impact wrench was well used and abused, making bad noise, had rusted bolts, seized bearing causing motor to keep spinning and rub against housing, melting the plastic clamshell body
Machine was making popping sounds and had a broken/unlit tip on the power lead cord

SDS drill was not holding the bit properly due to worn out keyways in the tool holder, plus had perished rubber bump stop, broken steel cap, and debris contamination inside requiring complete cleaning
Magnetic drill had electrical problems with a blown armature that was raised up and eating away the brushes, with visible burn damage
failure_reason: Repair cost of approximately 400 euros for motor replacement is not economically viable compared to buying a new equivalent machine for 600 euros

problem: Customer reported the grinder went 'bang' but upon inspection no fault could be identified - machine ran normally with only minor lead damage found
Off square and not cutting straight. The blade was sitting too far back and the base was dropped down, causing cuts to be out of square by 2-3 millimeters.
Chuck was stuck and jammed in the open position. The rubber cap was worn through from drilling too close to concrete walls, causing the chuck to lock down. The sleeve was twisted and rounded over.
component: chuck components (rubber cap, sleeve, spring, steel balls)

problem: Tool not working due to internal wire fatigue and breakage from constant vibration. Wire broke off at the motor pin with nothing left to reconnect to.
failure_reason: Wire broke at the motor pin with no material left to repair. Would require motor replacement which costs 70-80 euros, not economical for a tool worth 150 euros new.

problem: Not cutting straight, blade dropping over to one side. Tool holder/blade clamp was very stiff and damaged, not holding blades properly.
failure_reason: Tool holder is part of lifting rod and half the gearbox assembly, costing 120-130 euros to replace, which is not economical compared to buying a new jigsaw.

problem: Variable switch working intermittently, sometimes stopping dead completely. Eventually failed completely with no response.
failure_reason: Switch costs 50 euros but the machine can be bought new online for about 90 euros, making repair uneconomical.

problem: Complete failure with no LED light coming on, no response at all. Tool has been heavily used and abused on construction sites.
failure_reason: Controller failure on brushless machine. Controller replacement costs as much as the machine itself, making repair uneconomical.

problem: Not working despite LED light coming on. Switch failed and blew the MOSFET. Motor brushes worn and field coils weak. Machine heavily used by steel fabricator.
failure_reason: Needs switch (60 euros) and brushes (7 euros), but motor field is weak which likely caused switch failure. Risk of repeat failure too high, and machine can be bought new for about 160 euros.

problem: Trigger switch jammed all the way in and not responding properly. Switch mechanism had come out of its track/groove and was packed with metal swarf.
